subsection.title: Inverse Variation
subsection.p: If you are driving your car, you might average 50 miles per hour. Your travel time is then T = \frac{D}{R}= \frac{600}{50}= 12 \text{ hours}
If you take a commercial air flight, the planeâ€™s speed might be 400 miles per hour, and the flight time would be T = \frac{D}{R}= \frac{600}{400}= 1.5 \text{ hours}

You can see that for higher average speeds, the travel time is shorter. In other words, the time needed for a 600-mile journey is a decreasing function of average speed. In fact, a formula for the function is T = f (R) = \frac{600}{R}
This function is an example of inverse variationinverse variation. A table of values and a graph of the function are shown below.

image.description: graph of time vs average speed

assemblage.title: Inverse Variation
assemblage.p: y varies inverselyvaries inversely with x if y = \dfrac{k}{x}\text{, }x \ne 0 where k is a positive constant.

warning.p: Inverse variation describes a decreasing function, decreasing function but not every decreasing function represents inverse variation. People sometimes mistakenly use the phrase varies inversely to describe any decreasing function, but if y varies inversely with x, the variables must satisfy an equation of the form y = \dfrac{k}{x}, or xy = k.

subsection.p: To decide whether two variables truly vary inversely, we can check whether their product is constant. For instance, in the preceding travel-time example, we see from the table that RT = 600.

webwork.pg-code: $invvar = RadioButtons( ["Check whether \(xy\) is a constant.", "Check whether the function is decreasing.", "Check whether \(y\) is the reciprocal of \(x\).", "Check whether \(y/x\) is a constant."], 0, );

statement.p: How can you test whether a table for y=f(x) represents inverse variation?

solution.p: Check whether xy is a constant.

statement.p: How can you test whether a table for y=f(x) represents inverse variation?

li.p: Check whether xy is a constant.
Check whether the function is decreasing.
Check whether y is the reciprocal of x.
Check whether y/x is a constant.

subsection.title: Finding a Formula for Inverse Variation
subsection.p: If we know that two variables vary inversely and we can find one pair of corresponding values for the variables, we can determine k, the constant of variation.constant of variation

ol.li: Because I varies inversely with R, we know that I=\dfrac{k}{R}. To find the constant k, we substitute \alert{10} for I and \alert{12} for R. \alert{10} \amp =\dfrac{k}{\alert{12}} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Solve for}~k.} k \amp = 10 \cdot 12 = 120 So the formula is I=\dfrac{120}{R}.

li.p: We use the formula to complete the table.
A graph of I as a function of R is shown below.

ol.li: We substitute \alert{533.3} for R in the formula. I=\dfrac{120}{\alert{533.3}} = 0.225 The light bulb draws 0.225 amps of current.

We substitute \alert{12.5} for I in the formula and solve for R. \alert{12.5} \amp =\dfrac{120}{R} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Solve for}~R.} R \amp = \dfrac{120}{12.5} = 9.6 The toaster has a resistance of 9.6 ohms.

aside.p: \alert{\text{[TK]}}~~For more examples of inverse variation, see Section 5.5.1 and Section 5.5.3 of the Toolkit.

statement.p: Delbert's officemates want to buy a $120 gold watch for a colleague who is retiring. The cost per person is inversely proportional to the number of people who contribute.

li.p: Express the cost per person, C, as a function of the number of people, p, who contribute.
The graph of cost per person is
A graph is also shown below.

statement.p: Delbert's officemates want to buy a $120 gold watch for a colleague who is retiring. The cost per person is inversely proportional to the number of people who contribute.

li.p: Express the cost per person, C, as a function of the number of people, p, who contribute.

aside.p: \alert{\text{[TK]}}~~For more graphs of inverse variation, see Section 5.5.2

subsection.title: Inverse Variation with a Power
subsection.p: We can also define inverse variation with a power of the variable.

assemblage.title: Inverse Variation with a Power
assemblage.p: y varies inverselyvaries inversely with x^n if y = \frac{k}{x^n}\text{, }x \ne 0 where k and n are positive constants.

subsection.p: We may also say that y is inversely proportionalinversely proportionalproportionalinverselyproportionalinverselyinverse variation to x^n.

statement.p:
The intensity of electromagnetic radiation, such as light or radio waves, varies inversely with the square of the distance from its source. Radio station KPCC broadcasts a signal that is measured at 0.016 watt per square meter by a receiver 1 kilometer away.
Write a formula that gives signal strength as a function of distance.
If you live 5 kilometers from the station, what is the strength of the signal you will receive?
Graph your function in the window \text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 6 \text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 0.02

li.p: Let I stand for the intensity of the signal in watts per square meter, and d for the distance from the station in kilometers. Then I = \dfrac{k}{d^2}. To find the constant k, we substitute \alert{0.016} for I and 1 for d. Solving for k gives us \alert{0.016} \amp = \dfrac{k}{1^2} k \amp = 0.016 (1^2) = 0.016 Thus, I = \dfrac{0.016}{d^2}.
Now we can substitute \alert{5} for d and solve for I. I = \frac{0.016}{\alert{5}^2}= 0.00064 At a distance of 5 kilometers from the station, the signal strength is 0.00064 watt per square meter.

subsection.p: To summarize, an inverse variation is an example of a decreasing function, but not every decreasing function describes an inverse variation.decreasing function

assemblage.title: Test for Inverse Variation
assemblage.p: If the product ~yx^n~ is constant and n is positive, then y varies inversely with x^n.

subsection.p: The graphs of some typical inverse variations are shown below. They are versions of the basic graphs you studied in Section 5.3, but restricted to positive x-values only.

statement.p: Use the table to decide whether H could vary inversely with m^2.

solution.p: Yes, the product Hm^2 is the constant 0.6 for all pairs (m,H) in the table.

statement.p: Use the table to decide whether H could vary inversely with m^2.

solution.p: Yes, the product Hm^2 is the constant 0.6 for all pairs (m,H) in the table.

subsection.p: In Section 5.4, we considered the scaling property of direct variation. If y=kx and you double the value of x, then the value of y doubles also. If y=kx^2 and you double the value of x, then the value of y is multiplied by a factor of 2^2=4.
What happens when you double the input of an inverse variation?

solution.p: Suppose you weigh W pounds at distance D from the center of the Earth. Then W = \dfrac{k}{D^2}. At distance 2D, your weight will be w = \frac{k}{(2D)^2}= \frac{k}{4D^2}= \frac{1}{4}\cdot\frac{k}{D^2} = \frac{1}{4}W Your new weight will be \dfrac{1}{4} of your old weight. By a similar calculation, you can check that by tripling the distance, your weight will be reduced to \dfrac{1}{9} of its original value.
